metadata.h1: 5 Reasons Why I Became a Data Scientist
metadata.description: I always considered myself first and foremost a biologist and an environmentalist. My educational and career focus throughout my young adult life was driven by my eternal optimism and thirst for…

all_paragraphs: “There is no passion to be found in playing small — in settling for a life that is less than you are capable of living.” — Nelson Mandela
If you asked me a year ago if I knew what a data scientist was, I wouldn’t have had an answer.

I always considered myself first and foremost a biologist and an environmentalist. My educational and career focus throughout my young adult life was driven by my eternal optimism and thirst for learning more about the world we live in. Learning new things has always been my passion, to the point where I moved across the world to earn a Masters in Biology and became a research scientist.

What drew me to my research jobs was my desire to explore. I liked taking a deep dive into the data and using it to solve complicated, real-world problems. I learned how to use R during college and slowly started dabbling in other programming languages. It began as a hobby, but very quickly became a passion that made me reconsider my career path.

It is important to note that I talked to many friends and family members about the reasons why I wanted to pursue a new career as a data scientist and how I was going to do it. I researched different online programs and bootcamps and connected with people who went through the process before me. After a lot of consideration, I decided what was best for me was to complete a Data Science bootcamp part-time while continuing my full time job.
Switching careers was a difficult choice, but there were five main reasons that pushed me to become a data scientist:

In order to become a data scientist, you need to become a data driven thinker. That means you have to overcome your natural biases and use the data to help make business decisions. Data Science is an extremely challenging career where you will have to be a problem-solver. This means that you have to commit to a lifetime of continual learning, whether it is new packages, algorithms or complicated neural networks. That’s what makes data science challenging and exciting! The best part is that this way of thinking is extremely valuable no matter where your career takes you!

To be a successful data scientist, you need to be a ‘jack-of-all trades’. A data scientist needs to have a solid understanding of statistics and mathematics, have the ability to code, and most importantly, communicate the results of their data analyses in an easily digestible way to a variety of different audiences. Having all of these skills is hard to come by and extremely valuable in the job market.

For me, coming from an extremely specialized research background, I pigeon-holed myself into a very niche job market. Data Science allowed me to expand my skill set to become desirable in all industries.

Data Science is a field where there is always room to learn and improve. Every year, there is more and more demand for data in every industry. According to NodeGraph there were around 4.6 billion internet users around the world by the end of 2019! It is constantly evolving as new fields emerge, such as Big Data, Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, etc.

As a data scientist, it is important to keep up with new techniques and learn on the fly, but arguably the most crucial skill is being able to communicate the complex results of your data to nontechnical stakeholders and answer business questions. Learning about your domain and how to best implement your data results to improve is a constant learning process that will sharpen and grow your critical thinking skills.

This was very important on my list! I live in NYC and it is a competitive job market with an extremely high cost of living. One of the benefits of becoming a data scientist is that the demand has continually increased over the years with not enough supply. The required skill sets are difficult to fulfill so there is less competition for many desirable positions.

According to GlassDoor, the average salary for an entry level Data Scientist in the United States is around $107,801 a year!!! That nearly three times as much as I was offered for my first job as a lab technician! After a few years of experience, data scientists can expect around a $140,000 median base salary.
The last, most important, and undeniable reason that solidified my decision was:

To me, this was most important because I am one of those people that doesn’t think of the long term. When someone asks me where I see myself in 10 years, I never have a definite answer. The benefit of data science is that it opens up opportunities in all industries from healthcare to finance, e-commerce to national security! The skills you learn as a data scientist are transferable and won’t go out of style anytime soon. No matter the industry, the data scientist plays a pivotal role in making business decisions.
I hope this blog post can give you some insight into why data science may be right for you!
If you want to take the next steps in learning more about data science, check out my other blogpost for ways to improve your skills and get a jump start in learning!
